properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall expected tonight through Tuesday. A significant rainfall will begin tonight. General rainfall amounts of 30 to 50 mm are likely by Wednesday morning in a swath from Sault Ste. Marie to Kesagami Provincial Park. Rain may linger through Wednesday and into Thursday giving additional, although lesser amounts. Localized totals exceeding 75 mm are possible by Thursday. Environment Canada continues to monitor the situation. Rainfall warnings may be issued as necessary. Rainfall warnings are issued when 50 mm in 24 hours is expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-23T11:52:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-22T19:53:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3891371563.2020
Area: Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island, Elliot Lake - Ranger Lake, Fraserdale - Pledger Lake, Kapuskasing - Hearst - Smooth Rock Falls, Little Abitibi - Kesagami Lake, Timmins - Cochrane - Iroquois Falls, Gogama - Foleyet
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and large hail. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 6:36 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.

properties.Title: Update To Civil Emergency Alert Issued By Government Of Saskatchewan
properties.Summary:
Description: Update for the Civil Emergency Alert issued by the Government of Saskatchewan. The state of emergency in Saskatchewan remains in effect. UPDATE: Phase 4.1 of Re-Open Saskatchewan is effective June 22. Additional allowable activities in Phase 4.1 are: day camps, outdoor pools and spray parks and outdoor sports. UPDATE: For Northwest Region. The Northwest Region remains in Phase 2 of Re-Open Saskatchewan, however there are some activities and services from other Phases being permitted. Go to the Saskatchewan COVID website listed in the instructions for a complete list of allowable services and activities in the Northwest Region. During all Phases of Re-Open Saskatchewan all public health orders, which includes physical distancing by at least two metres from others, is to be followed and applied in all public and private gatherings.
Expires: 2020-06-29T17:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre, 2020-06-22T15:57:25-06:00, CD4B4924-CF22-8830-4518-373DF10C9E29
Area: Province of Saskatchewan
properties.Author: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warmer temperatures in the days ahead for inland areas of Nova Scotia Time span: Tuesday to Thursday. Maximum Temperature Tuesday and Wednesday: near 30 degrees Celsius (Humidex 36). Minimum temperatures Tuesday and Wednesday night: 18 Celsius. Locations: Annapolis Valley, Truro, Pictou and Antigonish areas. Remarks: Another run of very warm days is expected Tuesday to Thursday. Daytime high temperatures will be near 30 degrees with humidex values near 36. A break in the heat is likely on Thursday or Friday. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-23T10:44:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-22T18:45:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1781381991.2020
Area: Kings County, Annapolis County, Cumberland County - Minas Shore, Cumberland County North and Cobequid Pass, Colchester County - Cobequid Bay, Colchester County North, Hants County, Colchester County - Truro and south, Pictou County, Antigonish County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing damaging wind gusts, large hail and torrential rain. Boaters may be caught off guard by strong gusts on smaller bodies of water. ### Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-23T05:00:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-22T19:34:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1185813212.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 36 will continue. Heat event ending tonight. High temperatures in the upper twenties and humidex values in the mid thirties have been observed this afternoon. An approaching area of low pressure and its associated cold front will put an end to the heat and humidity by tonight. Please refer to your public forecast for further details. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Significant rainfall likely tonight through Tuesday. Rain, at times heavy, will begin tonight and continue through Tuesday. General rainfall totals of 40 to 60 mm are expected by Wednesday morning, although local amounts exceeding 75 mm are possible. Rain may linger Wednesday and into Thursday giving additional, although lesser amounts. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and large hail. Thunderstorms have developed in the region and are expected to move eastward throughout the afternoon and evening hours. The greatest threats associated with these thunderstorms are nickel to quarter size hail and wind gusts up to 80 km/h. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 39 are expected for the next 2 days. Warm conditions will continue well into the week. Time span: until Wednesday. Maximum temperatures Tuesday 30 to 32 degrees Celsius (Humidex 36 to 39). Minimum Temperatures tonight: near 18 degrees Celsius. Maximum temperatures on Wednesday 27 to 30 degrees Celsius (Humidex 33 to 36). Locations: New Brunswick except the Fundy region. Remarks: warm and humid conditions will continue Tuesday and Wednesday for most of New Brunswick. Southeastern areas may exceed warning criteria again on Thursday before a break in the heat. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
